Calegari has a nice introductory paper... or at least it starts out pitched at my level:

  • Motives and L-functions.

In Section 1.5 he starts by reviewing the Weil conjectures, and in Lemma 1.5.1 he points out an interesting relation between Galois representations and zeta functions. But before we even get to that, I'm confused about something.
He starts with a smooth projective variety XXX over Q\mathbb{Q}Q and then later starts talking about X(Fq)X(\mathbb{F}_q)X(Fq​) where q=ℓmq = \ell^mq=ℓm and ℓ\ellℓ is prime.

This makes it sound like you can unambiguously talk about the points of XXX over a finite field when XXX starts out defined over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. I don't see how. I can do it if XXX is defined over Z\mathbb{Z}Z for that. But he doesn't say anything about that. He doesn't say anything about choosing a model for XXX, which I gather is a way of defining it over Z\mathbb{Z}Z.
Is he just being relaxed and sloppy, or am I confused about something here?
He introduces XXX in section 1.3 as an algebraic variety "cut out by polynomial equations with rational coefficients", where it makes more sense to look at what happens over different fields.

I imagine he is doing the analogous thing for projective varieties, not fixing the variety and finding points of it but fixing the presentation of the variety in terms of equations and allowing the field in which those equations are interpreted to vary. This will be a valid thing to do for "most" characteristics of field, although if he had chosen integer coefficients things would have been less ambiguous.
That's my reading of it, I'm pretty sure my AG is weaker than yours though, John.

My point is that if you have a bunch of polynomial equations with rational coefficients, there's no systematic way to define their solutions in a finite field Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​, basically because there's no homomorphism Q→Fq\mathbb{Q} \to \mathbb{F}_qQ→Fq​. This problem applies both to affine and projective varieties.

If you choose a way to "clear denominators" and write your equations using integer coefficients, then you can talk about their solutions in any commutative ring RRR, since there's always a unique homomorphism Z→R\mathbb{Z} \to RZ→R.

But I believe different ways to clear denominators can give non-isomorphic results: choosing a way to do it is called choosing a 'model' of our original affine or projective variety over Q\mathbb{Q}Q.

There is sometimes a 'best' model of a variety over Q\mathbb{Q}Q, called the Neron model, defined by a universal property. Elliptic curves and more generally abelian varieties have such a model. But I believe not all varieties have a Neron model. (This is just my impression; I have never really studied Neron models.)

I have been avoiding the word "scheme" above, to avoid acting like I know more than I do, but perhaps you'd like me better if I said it more often! The link to Neron model talks in terms of schemes. A model of a scheme XXX over Q\mathbb{Q}Q is a scheme over Z\mathbb{Z}Z which upon base change along Z→Q\mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Q}Z→Q gives XXX. The Neron model, if it exists, is initial in a certain rather obvious sense. But the article says not every scheme has a Neron model. Since it says all abelian varieties do, in a somewhat excited tone of voice (in the quiet way that mathematicians are excited), I conclude that not all varieties do.

All this makes it impossible for me to take Calegari seriously when he starts with a smooth projective variety XXX over Q\mathbb{Q}Q and comes up with formula for the number of its points over a finite field! He's an infinitely better algebraic geometer than me so I think maybe a gear slipped when he was trying to write things in a simple way for beginners like me.

Does it matter that you might get different answers over Z\mathbb{Z}Z? We're immediately reducing mod ppp, and I think once you reduce you get the same answer unless you're going out of your way to choose a bad way to clear denominators

Write NNN for the least common multiple of all the junk appearing in the denominator of fff, which is the obvious thing to try. Then for any MMM (as long as ppp doesn't divide NMNMNM) NfNfNf and MfMfMf are the same (up to units) mod ppp. So once you fix a ppp that you're interested in, "most" ways to clear denominators give the same answer! Moreover, this answer will be the same as just clearing in the most obvious way (multiplying by NNN the lcm), so you might as well just do that.
Am I making some easy mistake? It's possible

If we think of an affine algebraic variety as presented by 'generators' (variables x1,x2,…x_1, x_2, \dots x1​,x2​,…) and 'relations' (polynomial equations Pj(x1,…,xn)=0P_j(x_1, \dots, x_n) = 0Pj​(x1​,…,xn​)=0), what worries me is that an affine algebraic variety doesn't come with a god-given presentation.

Once we choose a presentation, you're right that there's a clear strategy to get a presentation using only polynomials with integer coefficients: take each polynomial PjP_jPj​ and multiply it by the least common multiple of all the divisors of all the coefficients. But suppose we have two quite different-looking presentations....

I should cook up a concrete example, and study this generators and relations business in more detail - especially since it's fundamental in algebraic geometry: there can be 'relations between relations', called 'syzygies', and thinking about this led people to invent the concept of a 'resolution' of a module, and cohomology for modules of rings, and 'cofibrant replacement', and ultimately n-categories (since there can be relations between relations between relations...).

I've dived reasonably deep into some of this stuff, yet I'll have to work a bit to come up with a finitely generated Q\mathbb{Q}Q-algebra AAA that has different nonisomorphic but equally plausible 'Z\mathbb{Z}Z-forms', i.e. algebras over Z\mathbb{Z}Z which when tensored with Q\mathbb{Q}Q give AAA.

If you asked me for a C\mathbb{C}C-algebra that had different R\mathbb{R}R-forms I'd instantly say

⟨x,y∣x2+y2=1⟩ \langle x , y \vert x^2 + y^2 = 1 \rangle ⟨x,y∣x2+y2=1⟩

and

⟨x,y∣x2−y2=1⟩ \langle x, y \vert x^2 - y^2 = 1 \rangle⟨x,y∣x2−y2=1⟩

The circle and the hyperbola become the same over C\mathbb{C}C!
And I could talk about this in the fancy language of 'Galois descent', at least rather slowly and haltingly. But descending from Q\mathbb{Q}Q to Z\mathbb{Z}Z is not something I'm comfortable with.

What about this, then? It's more intrinsic, but it's also more likely that I'll make a mistake, since I'm using topological intuition that I'm not sure how to make precise in the AG world.

Let XXX be smooth and proper over Q\mathbb{Q}Q, if we can show it's still proper over Z\mathbb{Z}Z (composing with the unique map Q→Z\mathbb{Q} \to \mathbb{Z}Q→Z) then the image of the non-smooth locus "should be" closed in Z\mathbb{Z}Z, which means it corresponds to a single ideal (N)(N)(N). Then XXX should be everywhere smooth over Z[N−1]\mathbb{Z}[N^{-1}]Z[N−1]. Now you can reduce mod ppp (by base change) for any p∈Z[N−1]p \in \mathbb{Z}[N^{-1}]p∈Z[N−1]. That is, for all but finitely many primes.
Also sorry for not typing "Spec" everywhere. I'm on my phone, haha

Your approach is too abstract for my feeble brain. Luckily, I realized that my cute little "circle versus hyperbola" example can be modified to give a bunch of nonisomorphic affine schemes over Z\mathbb{Z}Z that become isomorphic over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. Namely, ellipses!

For example, the circle

⟨u,v∣u2+v2=1⟩ \langle u,v \vert u^2 + v^2 = 1 \rangle ⟨u,v∣u2+v2=1⟩

is isomorphic to the ellipse

⟨x,y∣x2+4y2=1⟩ \langle x, y \vert x^2 + 4 y^2 = 1 \rangle ⟨x,y∣x2+4y2=1⟩

as schemes over Q\mathbb{Q}Q, using the coordinate change

u↦x,v↦2y u \mapsto x, v \mapsto 2 y u↦x,v↦2y

This map is invertible as a map of schemes over Q\mathbb{Q}Q because we can define the inverse

x↦u,y↦v/2 x \mapsto u, y \mapsto v/2 x↦u,y↦v/2

But as a map of schemes over Z\mathbb{Z}Z it's not invertible because we can't divide by 2!

Indeed, there are infinitely many nonisomorphic schemes over Z\mathbb{Z}Z - different shapes of ellipses - that become isomorphic over Q\mathbb{Q}Q.

(And then there are infinitely many nonisomorphic ellipses over Q\mathbb{Q}Q that become isomorphic over R\mathbb{R}R, because in R\mathbb{R}R but not in Q\mathbb{Q}Q every positive number is a square. But this is captured by Galois descent in its classic form - i.e., Galois descent for field extensions!)

To sound like an algebraic geometer, instead of saying "ellipse" I should say "quadric". So, we've seen that a quadric over Q\mathbb{Q}Q has infinitely many different Z\mathbb{Z}Z-forms, also known as "models". The latter can then have different numbers of points over Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​, though apparently only for finitely many primes ppp.

For example,

⟨u,v∣u2+v2=1⟩ \langle u,v \vert u^2 + v^2 = 1 \rangle ⟨u,v∣u2+v2=1⟩

and

⟨x,y∣x2+4y2=1⟩ \langle x, y \vert x^2 + 4 y^2 = 1 \rangle ⟨x,y∣x2+4y2=1⟩

are dramatically different over F2\mathbb{F}_2F2​, but they're isomorphic over Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​ for all primes ≠2\ne 2=2, since in those fields 222 is invertible.
I should compute the zeta functions of these two quadrics and see if they're the same or not!
They should be a product of Euler factors, one for each prime, and these factors should agree except for the prime 222.

This was kind of my point earlier! Here's a proof theoretic angle, which might convince you, though I'm still not sure how to make it totally precise:

If XXX has two presentations over Q\mathbb{Q}Q, then there should be a proof of this fact (by which I mean something like a sequence of tietze transformations but for ring presentations). But any such proof is finitely long, so one only has to divide finitely many times. But then the same proof will work over any Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​ with ppp large enough for all those divisions to be allowed!
As an aside, I can't actually find anything on "tietze transformations for algebra presentations"... Surely someone has studied that, though! Does it have a different name?
This is also what I meant when I talked about '"most" characteristics of field'. It's nice to see how this issue is more subtle than I had imagined, though!!
